Definition: Magnitude of velocity of sound in water.

CF Definition: Speed is the magnitude of velocity.
Comments: CF map from Jeff DLB. Note that IOOS needs terms for composite phenomena e.g. winds = speed & direction & gust

Definition: Amount of pressure caused by overlying water column.
CF Definition: "Sea water pressure" is the pressure that exists in the mediumof sea water. It includes the pressure due to overlying sea water - sea ice - air and any other medium that may be present.
Comments: SEACOOS notes that the additional qualifiers "sea_water" should not be included in the Data Dictionary.  Some of the observations for the regional observing systems are not necessarily in full sea water.  How is CF defining "sea water" anyway?  Is there some specific ppt level?

Definition: In situ temperature of the ocean.
Y-coordinate of dependent observation in geographic coordinate. North is positive.
CF Definition: Latitude is positive northward; its units of degree_north (or equivalent) indicate this explicitly. In a latitude-longitude system defined with respect to a rotated North Pole - the standard name of grid_latitude should be used instead of latitude. Grid latitude is positive in the grid-northward direction - but its units should be plain degree.
Comments: CeNCOOS notes: GPS measured values of latitude and longitude are relative to WGS84 (particular geoid).

Definition: X-coordinate of dependent observation in geographic coordinate. East is positive.
CF Definition: Longitude is positive eastward; its units of degree_east (or equivalent) indicate this explicitly. In a latitude-longitude system defined with respect to a rotated North Pole - the standard name of grid_longitude should be used instead of longitude. Grid longitude is positive in the grid-eastward direction - but its units should be plain degree.degree_east  longitude
Comments: CeNCOOS notes: GPS measured values of latitude and longitude are relative to WGS84 (particular geoid).

Definition: Z-coordinate of observation in vertical distance above reference. Up is positive.  (sea surface | geiod | ellipsoid | MSL | MLLW | AGL)
average value

Upper 1-2  meters of an interface between two layers - commonly the sea surface.

Time coordinate of observation based on number of seconds since the defined reference time. (UDUNITS {sec | hr | day} since YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS.xxx {+/- ZONE})
Bottom of a layer - commonly ocean bottom.

Definition: Mass of water per unit volume

Definition: Radiance from below - leaving the water surface.
concentration of chloropyll-a in a defined volume of water
CF Definition: Mass concentration means mass per unit volume and is used in the construction mass_concentration_of_X_in_Y- where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. Chlorophyll is the green pigment found in most plants- algae and cyanobacteria. The presence of chlorophyll is essential for photosynthesis to take place. There are five different forms of chlorophyll that occur naturally. All contain a chlorin ring (chemical formula C20H16N4) which gives the green pigment and a side chain whose structure varies. The naturally occurring forms of chlorophyll contain between 35 and 55 carbon atoms.

Definition: Ratio of transmitted power to incident power
specific frequency of energy within the electromagnetic spectrum.

Definition: Amount of wet equivalent precipitation accumulated for a 24 hour period.
Amount of wet equivalent precipitation per unit time.
Direction from which wind is blowing.  Meteorological Convention.
CF Definition: Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector- with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.) In meteorological reports- the direction of the wind vector is usually (but not always) given as the direction from which it is blowing (wind_from_direction) (westerly- northerly- etc.). In other contexts- such as atmospheric modelling- it is often natural to give the direction in the usual manner of vectors as the heading or the direction to which it is blowing (wind_to_direction) (eastward- southward- etc.) "from_direction" is used in the construction X_from_direction and indicates the direction from which the velocity vector of X is coming.

Definition: Magnitude of wind velocity.
CF Definition: Speed is the magnitude of velocity. Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector- with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.) The wind speed is the magnitude of the wind velocity.

Definition: Maximum instantaneous wind speed (usually no more than but not limited to 10 seconds) within a sample averaging interval.
CF Definition: Speed is the magnitude of velocity. Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector- with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.) The wind speed is the magnitude of the wind velocity. A gust is a sudden brief period of high wind speed. In an observed timeseries of wind speed- the gust wind speed can be indicated by a cell_methods of maximum for the time-interval. In an atmospheric model which has a parametrised calculation of gustiness- the gust wind speed may be separately diagnosed from the wind speed.

Definition: Magnitude of wind stress. Wind stress is the force of wind imposed on a unit area.
Direction toward which wind stress is acting.
East/West component of wind vector. Eastward wind is positive.

Definition: North/South component of wind vector. Northward wind is positive.
CF Definition: "Northward" indicates a vector component which is positive when directed northward (negative southward). Wind is defined as a two-dimensional (horizontal) air velocity vector- with no vertical component. (Vertical motion in the atmosphere has the standard name upward_air_velocity.)

Definition: dissolved inorganic carbon
Possible Equivalent Term from CF V.13: ocean_mass_content_of_dissolved_inorganic_in_sea_water OR  mole_concentration of inorganic carbon in sea water
CF Definition: "Content" indicates a quantity per unit area. "Dissolvedinorganic carbon" describes a family of chemical species in solution- including carbon dioxide- carbonic acid and the carbonate and bicarbonate anions. "Dissolved inorganic carbon" is the term used in standard names for all species belonging to the family that are represented within a given model. The list of individual species that are included in a quantity having a group chemical standard name can vary between models. Where possible- the data variable should be accompanied by a complete description of the species represented- for example- by using a comment attribute. OR Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume- also called "molarity"- and is used in the construction mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y- where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. "Dissolved inorganic carbon" describes a family of chemical species in solution- including carbon dioxide- carbonic acid and the carbonate and bicarbonate anions. "Dissolved inorganic carbon" is the term used in standard names for all species belonging to the family that are represented within a given model. The list of individual species that are included in a quantity having a group chemical standard name can vary between models. Where possible- the data variable should be accompanied by a complete description of the speciesrepresented- for example- by using a comment attribute.

Definition: dissolved organic carbon
CF Definition: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called "molarity", and is used in the construction mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y, where Xis a material constituent of Y. A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. Organic carbon describes a family of chemical species and is the term used in standard names for all species belonging to the family that are represented within a given model. The list of individual species that are included in a quantity having a group chemical standard name can vary between models. Where possible, the data variable should be accompanied by a completedescription of the species represented, for example, by using a comment attribute.
sea_water_alkalinity_expressed_as_mole_equivalent' is the total alkalinity equivalent concentration (including carbonate- nitrogen- silicate- and borate components).

Definition: A velocity is a vector quantity. Radial velocity away from instrument means the component of the velocity along the line of sight of the instrument where positive implies movement away from the instrument (i.e. outward). The "instrument" (examples are radar and lidar) is the device used to make an observation.
CF Definition: A velocity is a vector quantity. Radial velocity away from instrument means the component of the velocity along the line of sight of the instrument where positive implies movement away from the instrument (i.e. outward). The "instrument" (examples are radar and lidar) is the device used to make an observation.

Definition: The direction_of_radial_vector_away_from_instrument is the direction in which the instrument itself is pointing. The direction is measured positive clockwise from due north. The "instrument" (examples are radar and lidar) is the device used to make an observation. "direction_of_X" means direction of a vector - a bearing.
CF Definition: The direction_of_radial_vector_away_from_instrument is the direction in which the instrument itself is pointing. The direction is measured positive clockwise from due north. The "instrument" (examples are radar and lidar) is the device used to make an observation. "direction_of_X" means direction of a vector - a bearing.

Definition: no definition but included in SEACOOS V.2. time (delta_t) between successive measurements

The largest value or upper limit of a quantity or measured value.
The lowest value or lowest limit of a quantity or measured value.
no definition but included in SEACOOS V.2. the closeness of the sensor measurement to the true value.
A defined or empirically derived standard deviation (sigma_t) for a given time difference (delta_t) for each parameter of interest. ﻿﻿Sigma-t is density of seawater -1000.
Comments: CF does have a "sea_water_sigma_t"- but CF's definition of "sea_water_sigma_t" is Sigma-t of sea water is the density of water at atmospheric pressure (i.e. the surface) having the same temperature and salinity- minus 1000 kg m-3. Note that sea water sigma is not the same quantity as the dimensionless ocean sigma coordinate (see Appendix D of the CF convention)- for which there is another standard name.SEACOOS notes: As for "sigma_t" and "sea_water_sigma_t"-  they do not share the same definition and sigma_t in the DD refers to a statistical variable (used for QC) where as CF refers to a property of water.  A better term for DD would be standard_deviation_with_time.  But please dissociate the two terms in your list.  CeNCOOS notes: The variable name should not be used for sigma (standard deviation of a value)….variance of measurment over some specified period of time.

Definition: The difference between the time of last acceptable measurement or value and the time of the measurement or value of interest.
The difference between the last acceptable measurement or value and the measurement or value of interest.
The check to ensure that all measurements or values fall within established upper and lower limits.

This test evaluates the rate of change of a parameter with time.  The difference between two consecutive measurements or values of a parameter (delta_m) is verified to be less than a maximum allowable change (sigma_t) defined for a specific time period (delta_t). If delta_m is greater than sigma_t then the measurement fails.  If delta_t is greater than maximumTime then the sigma_t evaluated for the maximumTime is used.
